question: Question_06_(c)
statement:
The purpose of this problem is to prove the following tThe purpose of
this problem is to prove the following theorem.

\textbf{Theorem 1.} For all positive integers $\displaystyle a,m$ we
have $\displaystyle a^{m} \equiv a^{m-\phi(m)} \mod{m}$

Let $\displaystyle a,m$ be positive integers. For $\displaystyle m=1$,
the theorem holds trivially, so we assume from now on that
$\displaystyle m > 1$ and write its prime-power factorization as
$\displaystyle m = p_{1}^{e_{1}} \cdot ... \cdot p_{k}^{e_{k}}$ for
different primes $\displaystyle p_{1},...,p_{k}$ and positive integer
exponents $\displaystyle e_{1},...,e_{k}$ and some positive integer
\emph{k}. Let $\displaystyle i \in \{1,..,k\}$ and focus on the prime
power $\displaystyle p_{i}^{e_{i}}$ in the prime-power factorization of
\emph{m}.

\textbf{(c)} Prove that
$\displaystyle p_{i}^{e_{i}} \mid (a^{n} - a^{m-\phi(m)})$

\emph{Hint:} Combine the results of
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH312/December_2008/Question_06_(a)}{(a)}
and
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH312/December_2008/Question_06_(b)}{(b)}.
sols:
We proceed in cases.

\textbf{Case 1\[\displaystyle p_{i} \nmid a\]}.

In this case, part (a) states that

$\displaystyle a^{\phi(m)}\equiv 1 \mod{p_{i}^{e_{i}}}$.

Since $\displaystyle \gcd(a,p_{i}^{e_{i}}) = 1$, the element above has
an inverse showing that

$\displaystyle a^{-\phi(m)}\equiv 1 \mod{p_{i}^{e_{i}}}$.

Multiplying both sides by $\displaystyle a^{m}$ yields

$\displaystyle a^{m-\phi(m)}\equiv a^{m} \mod{p_{i}^{e_{i}}}$.

which is what we wanted to show in this case.

\textbf{Case 2\[\displaystyle p_{i} \mid a\]}.

In part (b), we showed that

$\displaystyle p_{i}^{e_{i}} \mid a^{m-\phi(m)}$

Since

$\displaystyle a^{m - \phi(m)} \mid a^{m}$

We also have that

$\displaystyle p_{i}^{e_{i}} \mid a^{m}$

and hence that

$\displaystyle p_{i}^{e_{i}} \mid (a^{m} - a^{m-\phi(m)})$.
hints:
Split this problem up into the two cases as mentioned in parts (a) and
(b).
